title: Low-Dose Mapping of Ionic Channel Architectures in Fuel-Cell Polymer Membranes with Cryo-STEM-EELS
content: Advancing next-generation electrochemical devices, such as fuel cells and batteries, requires understanding the local architecture of polymer membranes at the nanoscale. Nonetheless, imaging these membranes is challenging due to their extreme beam sensitivity and inherent low contrast. Traditional TEM methods rely on heavy-element stains or ion-exchange for contrast enhancement in polymers, which may introduce artifacts due to incomplete or non-specific staining or swelling behavior [1]. Here, we demonstrate the use of cryogenic-STEM electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) for direct identification and quantitative analysis of the hydrophobic/hydrophilic microphase separation within polymer membranes in their unaltered form, a characteristic believed to enhance their ionic conductivity.
